turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: It was raining and her hair didn't look like that... damped out, I guess.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Tell me all about her.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: She arrived kind of late, wet and hungry and she was very tired and went right to bed and left early.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: How early?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Very early. Dawn.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Of which morning?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: The following morning. Sunday.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: No one met her?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Or arrived with her.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: She didn't call anyone? Even locally?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: You didn't spend the whole night with her did you?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: No! Of all...

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: How do you know she didn't make a call?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: She was tired. She said she had a long drive ahead of her, in the morning... Yes, now I'm remembering very clearly because I'm picturing. When you make a picture of the moment in your mind, you can remember every detail. She was sitting back there, no she was standing up, with some sandwich still in her hand, and she said she had to drive a long way.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Back where?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: You said she was sitting "back there," or standing rather...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Oh. My private parlor. She had an awful hunger... so I made her some supper. And then she went to bed and left in the morning. I didn't even see her leave.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: How did she pay you?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Cash or check? For the cabin...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Cash.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: And when she left, she never came back.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Why should she? I'm sorry, I have work to do, Mr... if you don't mind...

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: I do mind. If it don't jell, it ain't aspic!  This ain't jelling.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I don't know what you expect me to know about... people come and go...

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: She isn't still here, is she?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Not at all!

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Suppose I wanted to search the cabins, all twelve... would I need a warrant?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Look, if you won't believe me, go ahead. You can help me make beds if you like.  Come on.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I guess I've got one of those faces you can't help believing.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Anyone at home?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I live there. Alone.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Someone is sitting in that window.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: My mother.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: She's... ill. Confined to her room. It's practically living alone.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: If this girl Mary Crane were here, you'd have no reason to hide her would you?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: If she paid you well?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Now, look...!

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Or if she had you say... gallantly protecting her... you wouldn't be fooled... you'd know she was just using you. Wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I'm not a fool! And I'm not capable of being fooled! Not even by women!

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: I didn't mean that as a slur on your manhood. I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: That's all right. maybe she could have fooled me.  But...  She didn't fool my mother.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Your mother met her?  Can I talk to your mother?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: No. I told you, she's confined...

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Just for a moment. She might have picked up a hint you'd miss.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Sick old women are sharp. Come on, I won't disturb...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: No! Just no!  I have one of those breaking points like any other man, believe it or not, and I'm near it. There's just so much pushing I can take and I think...

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: All right!  Might save me a lot of leg-work if I could just talk to your mother.  But I'd need a warrant for that, won't I?

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Let's all talk about Mary.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Who are you, friend?

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Milt Arbogast, Private Investigator.  Where is she, Miss Crane?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What's your interest?

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Money.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Somebody better tell me what's going on and tell me fast! I can take so much and then...

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Your girl friend stole forty thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Must've needed it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What are you talking about?  What is this?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Did you check in Phoenix... hospitals... maybe she had an accident... a hold-up...

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: She was seen leaving town in her car. Seen by her very victims, I might add.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I don't believe it.  Do you?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Wouldn't have been able to tail you if you did.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Someone has seen her. Someone always sees a girl with forty thousand dollars.  She is your girl friend, isn't she?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Sam, they don't want to prosecute, they just want the money back. It was all in cash...

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: Casharoonie!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Sam, if she's here...

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: You came up here on a hunch, Miss Crane? Nothing more? No phone call... from him, or from your sister herself?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Not even a hunch. Just hope.

turns.speaker: ARBOGAST
turns.text: With a little checking, I could get to believe you.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I don't care if you do or... I want to see Mary... before she gets in any deeper...

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: I'm in no mood for trouble!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: There's an old saying, "First customer of the day is always the most trouble!" But like I said, I'm in no mood for it so I'm just going to treat you so fair and square you won't have one human reason to give me...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Can I trade in my car and take another?

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: You can do anything you've a mind to... and bein' a woman, you will!  That yours?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes, it's... nothing wrong with it, I'm just...

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: Sick of the sight of it!  Well, suppose you look around for something that strikes your eyes and meanwhile I'll have my mechanic give yours the once over and... want some coffee? I was just about...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No. Thank you. I'm in... a hurry. I just want to make a change and start...

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: That's the one I'd've picked for you myself!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: Go ahead! Spin it around the block. Now I know you don't know anything about engine condition, but you can feel, can't you... and it's all in the feel, believe me, you feel that one around the block...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It looks fine. How much will it be, with my car...?

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: You mean you don't want the usual day and a half to think it over?  You are in a hurry! Somebody chasin' you?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Of course not. Please.

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: Well... heck, this is the first time I ever saw the customer high-pressure the salesman!  I'd figure roughly...  ...your car plus five hundred.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Five hundred.

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: Aha! Always got time to argue money, huh...?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: I take it... you can prove that car's yours... I mean, out of state and all... got your pink slip and your...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I think I have the necessary papers. Is there a Ladies Room...

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: In the building ...  Mary starts for the building, glancing once in the direction of the Patrolman.

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: I think you'd better give it a trial spin. Don't want any bad word of mouth about California Charlie.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'd really rather not. Please.  Can't we just settle this and...

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: I'll be perfectly honest with you, Ma'am. It's not that I don't trust you, but...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But what?  Is there anything so terribly wrong about... making a decision and wanting to hurry? Do you think I've stolen... my car?

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: No, M'am. I was only about to say, I've sent my mechanic out to give your car a little test... that's all.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'd like to be ready when he gets back.

turns.speaker: CAR DEALER
turns.text: Okay. If you'll come along...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Isn't Mr. Lowery back from lunch?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: He's lunching with the man who's buying the Harris Street property, you know, that oil lease man...  so that's why he's late.  You getting a headache?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It'll pass. Headaches are like resolutions... you forget them soon as they stop hurting.

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: You got aspirins? I have something... not aspirins, but  my mother's doctor gave these to me the day of my wedding.  Teddy was furious when he found out I'd taken tranquilizers!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Were there any calls?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Teddy called.  Me... And my mother called to see if Teddy called. Oh, and your sister called to say she's going to Tucson to do some buying and she'll be gone the whole weekend and...

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Aren't you going to take the pills?  They'll knock that headache out.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't need pills... just sleep.

turns.speaker: CAROLINE'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Lowery.

turns.speaker: LOWERY'S VOICE
turns.text: Caroline...? Mary still isn't in?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE'S VOICE
turns.text: No, Mr. Lowery... but then she's always a bit late on Monday mornings.

turns.speaker: LOWERY'S VOICE
turns.text: Buzz me the minute she comes in.

turns.speaker: LOWERY'S VOICE
turns.text: Call her sister! If no one's answering at the house....

turns.speaker: CAROLINE'S VOICE
turns.text: I called her sister, Mr. Lowery, where she works, the Music Makers Music Store, you know? And she doesn't know where Mary is any more than we do.

turns.speaker: LOWERY'S VOICE
turns.text: You better run out to the house. She may be... unable to answer the phone...

turns.speaker: CAROLINE'S VOICE
turns.text: Her sister's going to do that.  She's as worried as we are.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Will you help us? I think something's wrong out there!

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Now. Your sister is missing how long?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: She left Phoenix a week ago yesterday. And no trace until...

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: How'd you and this detective come to trace her to Fairvale?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: She ain't missing so much as she's run away.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: She stole some money.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: A lot?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Forty thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: And the police haven't been able to...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Mary had been there, one night, and had left.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: With the forty thousand dollars?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: He didn't mention the money.  What he said on the phone isn't important, is it?  He was supposed to come back after he spoke to the mother, and he didn't! That's what I want you to do something about!

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Go out there! Find somebody, ask some questions!  I'm sorry if I seem over-anxious to you. I keep thinking... something's wrong. I have to know what!

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: I think something's wrong, too, Miss. But not the same thing. I think your private detective is what's wrong.  I think he got himself a hot lead as to where your sister was going... probably from Norman Bates...  and called you to keep you still while he took off after her and the money.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: He said he was dissatisfied... and was going back.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Please!

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Sorry I got you up, boy. Go back to sleep. Yeah, be glad to.  Said to give you his regards.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: You should've called in the police the second you found your sister has skipped. You go starting private investigations, using people you don't even know...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: What difference does that...

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Your Detective told you a nakedfaced lie.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Norman Bates' mother has been dead and buried in Greenlawn Cemetery for the last ten years!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Did he say anything about my sister?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Just what he told your detective.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I still feel...

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Can see you do. Sorry I couldn't make you feel better. You want to come to my office this afternoon and report a missing person... And the theft, is what you want to do!  Sooner you drop this thing in the lap of the law, that's the sooner you'll stand a chance of your sister bein' picked up. How about that?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: May I talk to you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Sure...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I'm Mary's sister.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Lila.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Is Mary here?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Is something wrong?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I want to know if my sister is here.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Here?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: With you.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I don't know where. In your store, somewhere in your town... anywhere.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Don't you know?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What should I know?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: To begin with, where Mary is. Do you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No. I take it you don't either?  How long?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Last Friday. She left work, and home... I was in Tucson over the weekend... I haven't heard from her, not even a phone call.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And you thought she'd come up here, to me? If she had, what reason would she have for not calling you?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: A good reason, I suppose.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well what do you think, we eloped or something? Or we're living in sin and...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Mr. Loomis, you're so busy being defensive that you haven't even reacted to the most serious fact of all. Mary is missing.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I was getting to that!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: What do you know about it?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Nothing! You're putting me on the defensive.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Look, if you two are in this thing together, I don't care, it's none of my business... But I want to see Mary. I want her to tell me she's all right and it's none of my business. Then I'll go back to Phoenix and...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What thing?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What thing could we be in together?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I hate tears.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Is Mary... in trouble?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well why didn't she come to me... call me...?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Not that kind...  You men and your egos.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Never mind my ego. Let's talk about Mary.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Yes... I just... did. The moment they told me...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You might have doubted for say five minutes or so, Sister.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I just listened... and believed everything they told me. 'She stole the money.' 'We don't want to get her in trouble.' 'No don't bring the police in'...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It was her boss' idea not to report it to the police?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: No. The man whose money she... he talked so loud and fast, and I... I should've called the police.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He must have had a darn good reason for wanting them kept out of it... All that cash...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I ought to call the police right now!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Why not? Sam, is she hiding here? Are you two planning to go away with the money?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: How could I go away? I'm in debt up to my...  If she did steal that money...  It's hard to believe she did because it's hard to see why she would. Unless she had some wild idea that it would help me... us...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: She haven't even called you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I didn't see her... and I didn't hear from her! Believe that!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I need to... I need to believe something. This is the first time I've ever come up against anything I couldn't... understand.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You've led a charmed life.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: No. I just think... anything can be explained. But Mary, doing a thing like this... I don't know how to handle...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Maybe we can handle it together.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I came flying up here expecting to get some explanation... for all I know, she may be trying to get in touch with me, at home. I'd better go home.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I think she'll contact me if she contacts anybody. Why don't you stay here. When she shows up... or calls... be here.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: You want me to stay here?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: She'll need both of us.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Where... can I stay?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: First rate hotel, fifty yards up the street. Come on.  After we check you in we'll go to the drugstore and get you a sandwich. Then we'll come back here... and wait.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Sometimes Saturday night has a lonely sound. Ever notice, Lila?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Sam. He said an hour. Or less.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It's been three.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Are we just going to go on sitting here?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He'll be back. Let's sit still and hang on, okay?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: You have an awfully nice habit, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hundreds! Which one is your pet?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Whenever I start contemplating the panic button, your back straightens up and your eyes get that God-looks- out-for-everybody look and... I feel better.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I feel better when you feel better.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Where's the old highway?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You want to run out there, bust in on Arbogast and the sick old lady, shake her up and maybe spoil everything Arbogast's been building for the last three hours.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: That wouldn't be a wise thing to do.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Patience doesn't run in our family. Sam, I'm going out there!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Arbogast said...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: An hour! Or less!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Got the number of the motel out on the old highway? Bates, I think.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Sam! Why call when we can go?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And maybe pass Arbogast on the road?  Thanks.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Probably on his way back right now.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Sam, I'm going.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You'll never find it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Stay here.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Why can't I go out there with you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I don't know...  One of us has to be here in case Arbogast's on the way.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Just wait here?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Contemplate your... panic button.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He didn't come back here?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No Arbogast. No Bates. And only the old lady at home...  A sick old lady unable to answer the door... or unwilling.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Where could he have gone?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Maybe he got some definite lead. Maybe he went right on...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Without calling me?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: In a hurry.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Sam, he called me when he had nothing definite, nothing but a dissatisfied feeling. Don't you think he'd have called if he had anything...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes. I think he would have.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Let's go see Al Chambers.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Who's he?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He's the Deputy Sheriff around here.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Our Deputy sleeps.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Nothing.  Just... all the lights out... must be asleep.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Does that mean we can't...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No. I'm just procrastinating.  People hate when the doorbell rings in the middle of the night.  Come on.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: No, thank you. It's my problem, too.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I don't know where to start...  Except at the beginning.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: This is Lila Crane, from Phoenix. She's been here for a few days, looking for her sister. There's a private detective helping... and, well, we got a call tonight, from this detective, saying he'd traced Mary...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I've only been here five. Right now it feels like ten, but...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: All right! Then call! At least, call!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Maybe I am the seeing-illusions type.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: You're not.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I won't feel satisfied unless I got out there, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Neither will I.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I wonder if we'll ever see Mary again.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Of course we will.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Alive.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Where'd you go to college?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I didn't. I got a job, too.  I wonder if that hurt her, my not letting her sacrifice for me?  Some people are so willing to suffer for you that they suffer more if you don't let them.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: She was willing to lick the stamps.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I wonder so many things about her now.  Why she never told me about you...  Funny, when you think there's an answer to everything, you think you know all the answers.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We were going to get married. Are going to get married!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Do you know how I found out about you? I found one of your letters... it was a nice letter, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: This is the old highway.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I suppose... when you were able to marry her she'd have presented you, all shiny and proper... she always tried to be proper.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Watch your tenses.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: She always tries to be proper.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: You going to wait here for me?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm going with you. But we'd better decide what we're going to say and do when we walk in...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: We're going to register. As man and wife. And get shown to a cabin... and then search every inch of that place, inside and... outside.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You won't believe it...  But this will be the first time I've ever pulled one of those man- and-wife-renting-cabin capers!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I believe it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I wonder where Norman Bates does his hermiting?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Someone was at that window. I saw the curtain move.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: We should have asked for Cabin One... The one Mary was in.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm glad we didn't.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: We have to go into that cabin and search it, Sam... no matter what we're afraid of finding and no matter how much it may hurt.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I know.  Do you think if something happened, it happened there?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Sam, if you owned a useless business like this motel... one you probably couldn't even sell...  what would you need to get away, to start a new business, somewhere else?  Forty thousand dollars?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: How could we prove...  Well, if he opens a new motel on the new highway... say, a year from now...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: There must be some proof that exists right now! Something that proves he got that money away from Mary... Some way!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What makes you sound so certain?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Arbogast! Sam, he liked me... or felt sorry for me... and he was starting to feel the same about you. I heard it when he called... in his voice, a caring. He wouldn't have gone anywhere or done anything without telling us.  Unless he was stopped. And he was stopped, so he must have found out something!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Hospital clean.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: The bathroom. Look at how clean it is. The one in our cabin is clean... but this is clean!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: It didn't get washed down. It's figuring... the kind you tear up and get rid of.  Some figure has been added to or subtracted from... forty thousand.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: That's proof Mary was here!  It would be too wild a coincidence for somebody else to...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Bates never denied Mary was here.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Yes.  But maybe this proves that Bates found out about the money.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Do we simply ask him where he's hidden it?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Sam, that old woman, whoever she is. I think she told Arbogast something! And I want her to tell us the same thing!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You can't go up there.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Bates.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It's regular. Okay?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I could stand something regular.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Call your boss and tell him you're taking the rest of the afternoon off. It's Friday anyway... and hot.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What do I do with my free afternoon, walk you to the airport?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We could laze around here a while longer.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Checking out time is three P.M. Hotels of this sort aren't interested in you when you come in, but when your time's up...  Sam, I hate having to be with you in a place like this.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I've heard of married couples who deliberately spend occasional nights in cheap hotels. They say it...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: When you're married you can do a lot of things deliberately.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You sure talk like a girl who's been married.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sam!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mary.  My old Dad used to say 'when you can't change a situation, laugh at it.' Nothing ridicules a thing like laughing at it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I've lost my girlish laughter.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: The only girlish thing you have lost.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sam. This is the last time.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: This! Meeting you in secret so we can be... secretive! You come down here on business trips and we steal lunch hours and... I wish you wouldn't even come.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Okay. What do we do instead, write each other lurid love letters?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I haven't time to argue. I'm a working girl.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And I'm a working man! We're a regular working-class tragedy!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It is tragic! Or it will be... if we go on meeting in shabby hotels whenever you can find a tax-deductible excuse for flying down deductible here...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You can't laugh at it, huh?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Can you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Sure. It's like laughing through a broken jaw, but...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And besides, when you say I make tax- deductible excuses you make me out a criminal.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You couldn't be a criminal if you committed a major crime.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I wish I were. Not an active criminal but... a nice guy with the conscience of a criminal.  Next best thing to no conscience at all.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I have to go, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I can come down next week.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Not even just to see you, to have lunch... in public?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We can see each other, we can even have dinner... but respectably, in my house with my mother's picture on the mantel and my sister helping me broil a big steak for three!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And after the steak... do we send Sister to the movies and turn Mama's picture to the wall?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sam! No!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Mary, whenever it's possible, tax- deductible or not, I want to see deductible you. And under any conditions.  Even respectability.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You make respectability sound... disrespectful.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm all for it! It requires patience and temperance and a lot of sweating- out... otherwise, though, it's only hard work.  But if I can see you, touch you even as simply as this... I won't mind.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm fed up with sweating for people who aren't there. I sweat to pay off my father's debts... and he's in his grave... I sweat to pay my ex-wife alimony, and she's living on the other side of the world somewhere.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I pay, too. They also pay who meet in hotel rooms.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: A couple of years and the debts will be paid off. And if she ever re- marries, the alimony stops... and then...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I haven't even been married once yet!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah, but when you do... you'll swing.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sam, let's go get married.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And live with me in a storeroom behind a hardware store in Fairvale. We'll have a lot of laughs. When I send my ex-wife her money, you can lick the stamps.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'll lick the stamps.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You know what I'd like? A clear, empty sky... and a plane, and us in it... and somewhere a private island for sale, where we can run around without our... shoes on.  And the wherewithal to buy what I'd like.  Mary, you want to cut this off, go out and find yourself someone available.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm thinking of it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: How can you even think a thing like that!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't miss your plane.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hey, we can leave together can't we?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm late... and you have to put your shoes on.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Dirty night.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You have a vacancy?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: We have twelve vacancies. Twelve cabins, twelve vacancies.  They moved away the highway.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I thought I'd gotten off the main...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I knew you must have. No one stops here anymore unless they do.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Your home address. Oh, just the town will do.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Los Angeles.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I want sleep more than anything. Except maybe, food.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: There's a big diner about ten miles on up... just outside Fairvale.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Am I that close to Fairvale?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Fifteen miles. I'll get your bags.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Stuffy in here.  Well... the mattress is soft and there're hangers in the closet and... stationary with "Bates' Motel" printed on it in case you want to make your friends back home envious... and... the... over there....

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: The bathroom.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I'll be in the office if you want anything... just tap on the wall.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thank you, Mr. Bates.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Norman Bates.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: You have something most girls never have.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I have?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: There's no name for it... But it's something that, that puts a person at ease.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thank you. Again.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: You're not going to go out again and drive up to that diner, are you?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Then will you do me a favor?  Will you have supper here?  I was just about to, myself... nothing more than some sandwiches and a lot of milk, but I'd like it if you'd come up to the house and... I don't set a fancy table but... the kitchen's awful homey.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'd like to.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: All right, you get your dresses hanging out and... change those wet shoes, and I'll come for you soon as it's ready...  ...with my trusty umbrella.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I've caused you some trouble.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Mother...  ...what is the phrase... "she isn't herself today"... I think that's it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You shouldn't have bothered. I really don't have that much of an appetite.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I'm sorry. I wish... people could apologize for other people.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't worry about it.  But as long as you've made us supper, we may as well eat it. Huh?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You're very... kind.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: It's all for you. I'm not hungry. Please go ahead.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: You eat like a bird.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You'd know, of course.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Not really. I hear that expression, that one eats "like a bird," is really a falsie, I mean a falsity, because birds eat a tremendous lot.  Oh, I don't know anything about birds. My hobby is stuffing things... taxidermy. And I guess I'd just rather stuff birds because...  well, I hate the look of beasts when they're stuffed, foxes and chimps and all... some people even stuff dogs and cats... but I can't... I think only birds look well stuffed because they're rather...  passive, to begin with... most of them...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's a strange hobby. Curious, I mean.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Uncommon, too.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I imagine so.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: It's not as expensive as you'd think. Cheap, really. Needles, thread, sawdust .. the chemicals are all that cost anything.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: A man should have a hobby.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: It's more than a hobby... sometimes... a hobby is supposed to pass the time, not fill it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Is your time so empty?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Oh, no!  I run the office, tend the cabins and grounds, do little chores for mother... the ones she allows I might be capable of doing.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You go out... with friends?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Friends? Who needs friends.  A boy's best friend is his mother.  You've never had an empty moment in your whole life. Have you?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Only my share.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Where are you going? I don't mean to pry...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm looking for a private island.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: What are you running away from?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why do you ask that?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: No. People never run away from anything.  The rain didn't last very long.  You know what I think? I think we're all in our private traps, clamped in them, and none of us can ever climb out. We scratch and claw... but only at the air, only at each other, and for all of it, we never budge an inch.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sometimes we deliberately step into those traps.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I was born in mine. I don't mind it anymore.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You should... mind it.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Oh I do... but I say I don't.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: If anyone ever spoke to me, the way I heard... The way she spoke to you, I don't think I could ever laugh again.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Sometimes when she talks that way to me I'd like to... curse her out and leave her forever!  Or at least, defy her.  But I couldn't. She's ill.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: She sounded strong...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I mean... ill.  She had to raise me all by herself after my dad died... I was only five... and it must have been a strain. Oh, she didn't have to go out to work or anything, Dad left us with a little something... anyway, a few years ago... Mother met a man. He talked her into building this motel... We could have talked her into anything... and when.  Well... It was just too much for her when he died, too... And the way he died... Oh, it's nothing to talk about when you're eating.  Anyway, it was too much of a loss for my mother... she had nothing left.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Except you.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: A son is a poor substitute for a lover.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why don't you go away?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: To a private island, like you?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, not like me.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: It's too late for me. And besides... who'd look after her? She'd be alone up there, the fire would go out... damp and cold, like a grave. When you love someone, you don't do that to them, even if you hate them. Oh, I don't hate her.  I hate... what she's become. I hate... the illness.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Wouldn't it be better if you put her in... someplace...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: An Institution? A madhouse?  People always call a madhouse "someplace."  Put her in Someplace!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm sorry... I didn't mean it to sound uncaring...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: What do you mean about caring?  Have you ever seen one of those places? Inside? Laughing and tears and cruel eyes studying you... and my mother there?  Why? has she harmed you? She's as harmless as... one of these stuffed birds.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I am sorry. I only felt... it seemed she was harming you. I meant...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Well? You meant well?  People always mean well, they cluck their thick tongues and shake their heads and suggest so very delicately that...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I've suggested it myself. But I hate to even think such a thing.  She needs me... and it isn't...  ...it isn't as if she were a maniac, a raving thing... it's just that... sometimes she goes a little mad. We all go a little mad sometimes. Haven't you?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes, and just one time can be enough.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Thank you, Norman.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Norman.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: You're not going to... to your room already?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm very tired. And I'll have a long drive tomorrow. All the way back to Phoenix.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Phoenix?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I stepped into a private trap back there -- and I want to go back and... try to pull myself out.  Before it's too late for me, too.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Why don't you stay a little while, just for talking.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'd like to, but...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Alright. I'll see you in the morning. I'll bring you breakfast.  What time will you...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Very early. Dawn.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Alright, Miss...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Crane.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: That's it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: In quite a hurry.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes.  I didn't mean to sleep so long. I was afraid I'd have an accident last night, from sleepiness... so I decided to pull over...

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: You slept here all night?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes. As I said, I couldn't keep my eyes...

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: There are plenty of motels in this area. You should have... I mean, just to be safe...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I didn't intend to sleep all night! I just pulled over... have I broken any laws?

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: No, m'am.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Then I'm free to go...?

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: Is anything wrong?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Of course not! Am I acting as if... something's wrong?

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: Frankly, yes.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Please... I'd like to go...

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: Is there?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Is there what?  I've told you there's nothing wrong... except that I'm in a hurry and you're taking up my time...

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: Now wait just a moment! Turn your motor off, please.

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: In the course of my duty, I never "take up" anyone's time, whether it's to give a warning, or a ticket, or help! Believe that, M'am.  Now if you woke up on the wrong side of... the car seat, that's one thing. But when you act as if I've just placed you under arrest...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: No need to apologize...

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: Wait a minute!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Now what?

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: May I see your license?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: PATROLMAN
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Sorry, Mrs. Chambers. I hate bothering you...

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: You didn't!  It's tinkerbell.  Al wants to be sure he'll hear it if anyone rings it in the middle of the night.  Well come on in, at least!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We have a problem.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Let's go out back and have some coca while the men are talking.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Mary is Lila's sister?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes. He traced her to that motel, out on the old highway...

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Bates' Motel.  He has a mind like a mechanical brain and the more information you feed it... Go on, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He traced her there and called us to say he was going to question Mrs. Bates...

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Norman took a wife?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No. An old woman, his mother.  That was early this evening. And we haven't seen or heard from him since. I went out to the motel, just got back. No one was in the office, and...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You mean that old woman I saw sittin' in the window wasn't Norman Bates' mother?

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Maybe you saw Mary!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'd know the difference between Mary and an old woman.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We thought, if you didn't mind, we'd go out to the motel with you.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: He's already been.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Why don't you call Norman and let him say just what happened, if he give the man a hot lead and he did just scooted off... it'll make the girl feel better, Albert.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: At this hour?

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Recluse. Kinder word.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: You must remember that bad business out there. About ten years ago...

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Norman? Sheriff Chambers.  Been just fine, thanks. Listen, we got some worries here. Did you have a man stop out there tonight...  Well, this one wouldn't be a customer, anyway. A private detective, name of...

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Arbogast.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Arbogast.  And after he left?  No, it's okay, Norman. How's it been going out there?  Well, I think you oughta unload that place and open up closer in to the action, a smaller place, you know... but...

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Barefaced.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: He told you he wasn't coming right back cause he wanted to question Norman Bates' mother, right?

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: I helped Norman pick out the dress she was buried in. Periwinkle blue.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: It ain't only local history, Sam, it's the only murder-and-suicide case in Fairvale ledgers! Mrs. Bates poisoned this guy she was... involved with, when she found out he was married, then took a helping of the same stuff herself.  Strychnine. Ugly way to die.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Norman found them dead together.  In bed.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Went out before service.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHAMBERS
turns.text: Have you two had breakfast?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Just coming up to ring for you.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I suppose you want a cabin.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We'd hoped to make it straight to San Francisco, but we don't like the look of that sky. Looks like a bad day coming... doesn't it.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I'll take you to...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Better sign in first, hasn't we?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: It isn't necessary.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Uh, uh! My boss is paying for this trip... ninety percent business... and he wants practically notarized receipts. I better sign in and get a receipt.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I'll get your bags.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Haven't any.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I'll show you the cabin.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Looking for me?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes, matter of fact.  The wife's taking a nap and... I can never keep quiet enough for her... so I thought I'd look you up and... talk.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Satisfied with your cabin?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I've been doing all the talking so far, haven't I?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I always thought it was the people who are alone so much who do all the talking when they get the chance. Yet there you are, doing all the listening!  You are alone here, aren't you?  It would drive me crazy.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: That would be a rather extreme reaction, wouldn't it?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Just an expression...  What I meant was... I'd do just about anything... to get away.  Wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm not saying you shouldn't be contented here, I'm just doubting that you are. I think if you saw a chance to get out from under... you'd unload this place...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: This place! This isn't 'a place.' It's my only world. I grew up in that house back there. I was a happy child. My mother and I... we were more than happy.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And now that your mother's dead?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: My mother is not dead!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I didn't think so.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You look frightened. Have I been saying something frightening?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I don't know what you've been saying.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I've been talking about your mother... about your motel. How are you going to do it?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Do what?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Buy a new one! In a new town! Where you won't have to hide your mother!

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Where will you get the money to do that, Bates... or do you already have it... socked away... a lot of it...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Leave me alone!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: ...Forty thousand dollars!

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Leave me alone!
